**Sol Valtiva** is an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"). It replaces [the Orb of Fate](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Fate "The Orb of Fate") as the [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact") for [Valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie") and the prize for completing the [Valkyrie quest](/wiki/Valkyrie_quest "Valkyrie quest"). It is [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic") for [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") purposes, and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword") made of [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril").

Sol Valtiva is the signature weapon of [Lord Surtur](/wiki/Lord_Surtur "Lord Surtur"), the Valkyrie quest nemesis, which is why it is chaotic-aligned.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Generation

Unlike most quest artifacts, Sol Valtiva is not guaranteed to be [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") when it generates in the Valkyrie quest, and it may have a negative [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment").

## Description

Sol Valtiva provides +1d3 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit"), and it deals +1d5 extra damage against monsters without [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance"). Like [Fire Brand](/wiki/Fire_Brand "Fire Brand"), it can destroy the target's [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion"), [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll"), and [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") and can instakill [green slimes](/wiki/Green_slime "Green slime") and flammable [golems](/wiki/Golem "Golem").

Like the Orb of Fate, Sol Valtiva provides [half physical damage](/wiki/Half_physical_damage "Half physical damage") and [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage") when carried (not just when wielded), and it can be [invoked](/wiki/Invoke "Invoke") to [level teleport](/wiki/Level_teleport "Level teleport"). However, it does not provide [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") or act as a [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone").

## Strategy

Sol Valtiva is rather heavy, though less so than the Orb of Fate it replaces, and its solid damage as a weapon and half damage properties may be worth the weight. Chaotic players wishing for an artifact may consider it over [the Master Key of Thievery](/wiki/The_Master_Key_of_Thievery "The Master Key of Thievery"), which is much lighter but lacks half spell damage.

## Encyclopedia entry

This flaming sword was created in the fires of Muspelheim and  
shines brightly with the red light of the sunset. It is a  
powerful artifact: damage, both spell and physical, is partially  
absorbed by the sword itself, and when invoked it has the power  
to teleport the invoker between levels.
